required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Physical Therapy Components for Maximum TKR Outcome
clinical_study.official_title: Defining Components of Physical Therapy Achieving Maximum Function After Total Knee Replacement

brief_summary.textblock: The overall goal of this study is to identify what Physical Therapy care components are associated with the best patient-reported functional outcome after Total Knee Replacement (TKR) surgery. The investigators are specifically looking at outcomes at 6 and 12 months after surgery.

primary_outcome.measure: Differences in overall functional gain at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Differences in pre-operative to 6 month post -operative functional gain, using the SF-36 Physical Component Summary (PCS) Score by physical therapy regimen.

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in knee specific functional gain at 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: Differences in pre-operative to 6 month post-operative functional gain, using the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS) Activities of Daily Living (ADL) by physical therapy regimen.

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in knee performance measures at 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: Differences in pre-operative to 6-month post -operative knee performance measures using the Physical Therapy Performance Measures (includes a 5 minute stair climbing exercise, a 6 minute walking exercise and a sit to stand exercise) by physical therapy regimen.

study_pop.textblock: Patients electing total knee replacement at one of 3 participating sites.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Are scheduled to undergo an elective, unilateral primary total knee replacement due to knee osteoarthritis
- Will receive outpatient PT from a participating physical therapist.
- Agree to record their exercise and activity for specific time points in the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Total knee replacement scheduled for indications other than OA (e.g., fracture, malignancy, infection, or revision or prior implant)
- The inability to obtain informed consent due to cognitive conditions.
- Non-English speakers as the materials used in this project have not yet been tested with non-English speakers
- Individuals who are not yet adults (infants, children, teenagers)
- Pregnant women
- Prisoners
